data.heading: Introduction
data.instructions:
This document describes needs of product stakeholders as agile user stories. User stories are simple statements formulated according to the following template:

“As a <type of user>, I want <some goal>, so that <some reason>.”

For more information see User Stories Applied by Mike Cohn or his User Stories web page.

children.heading: Purpose
children.instructions: Identify the product specified in this document.

children.text:
The main purpose of this document is to provide new users a working example of a document describing high-level user needs by means of user stories.

Note: This is an example document, which is not complete.

children.heading: Scope Modified
children.instructions: Briefly describe the scope of the product.

children.text: This document specifies requirements for a simple application for requirements management of software and system products.

Users should be able to:

  • Capture requirements specifications
  • Manage requirements using custom attributes
  • Set up requirements traceability
  • Browse the requirements traceability matrix (RTM)
  • Control Project Changes
  • Filter and search requirements
  • Import requirements from MS Word or Excel
  • Export requirements to DOCX, XLSX, PDF, HTML, or CSV
  • Analyze requirements coverage and impact of changes
  • Print requirements specifications
Note: The application functionality corresponds to ReqView v1.0 released in 2015. Check all advanced requirements management features it offers now.

children.heading: User Roles
children.instructions:
Identify user roles for the product and for each role describe characteristics of a typical user.

You may consider creating personas with a real name. Each persona should be described sufficiently that everyone on the team feels like they know the persona.

children.heading: Requirements Architect
children.text:
Requirements Architect defines requirements model and configure the requirements project for other users.

Requirements Architect is typically a QA manager or project manager.
children.iWant:
• Define custom attributes
  • Configure project traceability
  • Create document templates

children.heading: Editor
children.text:
Editor defines project requirements and creates requirements and tests documents.

Editor is typically a requirements engineer, business analyst, project manager, QA engineer or a tester.
children.iWant:
• Capture structured requirements
  • Update requirements custom attributes
  • Discuss requirements
  • Maintain requirements traceability links
  • Print requirements
  • Import requirements
  • Export requirements
  • Create traceability reports

children.heading: Reviewer
children.text:
Reviewer reads project documents, performs review and provides feedback for improving the content of the document.

Reviewer is typically an internal QA expert reviewing requirements and tests, customer or supplier commenting requirements and setting the requirement acceptance state.
children.iWant:
• Provide feedback to requirements specifications
  • Update requirements review status
  • Print requirements

data.heading: User Stories
data.instructions:
Specify user stories describing functionality of the product grouped into epics for easier navigation in the document.

Set the following attributes for each story:

  • Heading: short story name,
  • As a(n): type of user,
  • I Want: some goal,
  • So that: some reason,
  • Acceptance Criteria: more details how the story should be verified and providing the basic criteria that can be used to determine if a story is fully implemented,
  • Priority: “High” for fundamental features, “Medium” for important features having a short-term workaround, “Low” for features which can be left out of the release if time runs out or won't-have for features will be needed in a later release,
  • Risk: “High”, “Medium”, or “Low”,
  • Estimation: story points which are relative estimate of the complexity, effort or duration of a story, and
  • Status: workflow information classifying stories as “New”, “Planned”, “Implemented” or “Verified”.

children.heading: Document Files
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • saving project in a file
  • opening project from a file
children.soThat: users can open the document for further editing or review

children.heading: Document Templates
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • saving a document as a document template file,
  • add a new document into a project from a saved document template file while preserving document attributes definition, values of object attributes and object attachments.
children.iWant: save a document as a template file
children.soThat: I can reuse the document structure and configuration of custom attributes for new documents

children.heading: Autosave
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool:

  • instantly saves all the changes,
  • restores the same project content when it is restarted.
children.soThat: I do not lose my changes if the tool is unexpectedly terminated before saving into a file

children.heading: Requirement Description
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • setting a description of a selected requirement
  • removing description of a selected requirement
children.soThat: the requirements can be reviewed by other users.

children.heading: Unique IDs
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • automatic generation of document ID which can not be further changed
children.soThat: I can reference requirements from other documents or communication

children.heading: Document Structure
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • creation of a new project,
  • adding a new document into a project,
  • deletion of a document from a project.
children.iWant: organize requirements in a tree document hierarchy with numbered sections
children.soThat: I can easily navigate in the document structure

children.heading: Table View
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • displaying of requirements in a table,
  • displaying requirements ID, description, discussion, links and custom attributes in columns,
  • hiding requirements table columns,
  • reordering of requirements table columns,
  • resizing of requirements table columns.
children.soThat: I can review all requirements information in a single view

children.heading: Detailed View
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • displaying custom attributes of the selected requirement in a pane or dialog,
  • displaying discussion of the selected requirement in a pane or dialog,
  • displaying traceability links for the selected requirement in a pane or dialog,
  • displaying history of changes for the selected requirement in a pane or dialog.
children.iWant: display all information about the selected requirement
children.soThat: I can display details about any requirement which are not visible in the requirements table

children.heading: Attachments
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • attachment of image file to document objects,
  • displaying image attachments in the context of the related document object,
  • deletion of attachments
children.iWant: attach images and other documents to requirements
children.soThat: I can enhance textual requirements with visual content such as mockups, diagrams, etc.

children.heading: Sort
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports sorting requirements by:

  • the natural document order,
  • value of a custom attribute.
children.iWant: order requirements by a chosen custom attribute
children.soThat: I can display requirements sorted by priority, risk, effort, etc.

children.heading: Custom Attributes Configuration
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • creation of a new custom attribute,
  • deletion of a custom attribute,
  • definition of following custom attribute types
    • number
    • date
    • boolean
    • single and multivalue enumeration
    • string / rich formatted text
children.soThat: the document can flexibly store additional requirement properties, such as requirement source, priority, status, etc.

children.heading: Custom Attributes Modified
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • setting requirements source, priority, status and acceptance criteria
  • setting and resetting a value of a custom attribute for multiple requirements
children.iWant: set a value of a chosen custom attribute for one or more selected requirements
children.soThat: I can define additional requirements properties, such as requirements source, prioritize requirements, manage requirement status, define acceptance criteria, etc.

children.heading: Traceability Configuration
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • creation of at least one link type
  • definition of a start and end role for a link type
  • removal of a link type including all existing links
children.soThat: users can perform traceability analysis for a chosen group of links

children.heading: Traceability Links
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • creation of links with chosen link type between selected requirements,
  • deletion of links
children.soThat: I can analyze requirements coverage, gap in requirements and impact of requirement changes.

children.heading: Filter
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports filtering requirements:

  • by full text search in the object heading, text or a custom attribute
  • with the given traceability link type
  • in the given section
children.soThat: I can identify and manipulate requirements matching a condition

children.heading: Search
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool supports searching requirements containing a given keyword.
children.soThat: I can identify and manipulate requirements containing the searched keyword(s)

children.heading: Discussion
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • commenting a selected requirement,
  • displaying discussion for a selected requirement.
children.soThat: I can provide feedback during requirements review

children.heading: Traceability Browser
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • displaying linked requirements ordered by link type
  • changing focus to a selected requirement
  • filtering requirements with missing traceability links of a given link type
children.soThat: I can perform coverage, gap and change impact analysis

children.heading: Print
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • printing a document with the same layout as it is displayed,
  • saving the document as PDF with the same layout as it is displayed.
children.soThat: I can review requirements without the need to run the tool

children.heading: History of Changes
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • displaying history of changes for a selected requirement.
children.soThat: I can understand how the requirement evolved in time

children.heading: Traceability Report
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • generation of a custom traceability report which visualizes end-to-end requirements traceability
children.soThat: I can analyze coverage, gaps and impact of requirements changes

children.heading: Import from Word
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • import of MS Word HTML preserving structure of document sections and paragraphs and image attachments
  • pasting of a text or a HTML fragment to requirements description.
children.iWant: import a requirements specification from a MS Word document
children.soThat: I can reuse existing requirements specifications or other structured documents

children.heading: Import from Excel
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • import of new requirements from a CSV file including custom attribute values
  • updating requirements from a CSV file including custom attribute values
children.iWant: import requirements from a MS Excel spreadsheet
children.soThat: I can import or update list of requirements

children.heading: Export to Word
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • export of a document to a HTML file,
  • import of an exported HTML file to a MS Word document preserving requirements structure and content
children.iWant: to export structured requirements specification to MS Word
children.soThat: I can share requirements specifications with users without the tool

children.heading: Export to CSV
children.acceptanceCriteria:
Tool supports:

  • export of filtered list of requirements to a CSV file.
children.iWant: export filtered list of requirements to MS Excel
children.soThat: I can reuse or update requirements in another application

children.heading: Startup Time
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool starts in less than 10s even for large projects.
children.soThat: I do not need to wait long time for editing a project

children.heading: Edit Response Time
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool updates view after any edit operation in a document with 10000 requirements in less than 1s.
children.soThat: I can work without waiting for tool responses

children.heading: Document Size
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool can store documents with 10000 requirements and 100 attachments of total size 100 MB.
children.soThat: I can capture all requirements in a single document even for complex system development projects

children.heading: Security
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool stores all project data in an encrypted persistent application storage and does not send any project information to the internet without user consent.
children.soThat: I can be sure that no confidential information is sent to the Internet or is compromised by an unauthorized application

children.heading: Compatibility
children.acceptanceCriteria: Tool runs in the latest version of Chrome and Firefox browsers on Windows PC, Linux PC and a Mac.
children.soThat: I run the tool on my computer running Windows, Linux or Mac operating system without a need to install it
